title: How to Make Fruit Salsa

steps.headline: Prep your fruits.
steps.description: Peel the kiwis and apples, then core the apples and strawberries. Dice the kiwis, apples, and strawberries. Leave the raspberries whole. For best flavor, use Golden Delicious apples.

steps.headline: Combine the ingredients.
steps.description: Toss the diced kiwis into a large bowl. Add the apples, strawberries, and raspberries. Gently stir everything together to combine.

steps.headline: Add the sugar and fruit preserves.
steps.description: You can use any flavor of fruit preserves, but strawberry would taste the best. You can also use more or less sugar, depending on your personal tastes. Give your salsa a gentle toss after adding in the sugar and preserves.

steps.headline: Chill the salsa for 15 minutes before serving it.
steps.description: Cover the bowl with a sheet of plastic wrap. Place it in the fridge, and leave it there for 15 minutes. This will allow the flavors to blend. It will also make the salsa more refreshing.

steps.headline: Prepare your ingredients.
steps.description: Peel the papaya and the mango, then slice them in half and remove the seeds/pit. Dice them finely. Peel off the outer layer of the onion. Chop it into fine pieces. Mince the fresh jalapeño chile. You will need the seeds as well. Lastly, chop up the cilantro.

steps.headline: Stir the fruits and vegetables together in a bowl.
steps.description: Toss the papaya, mango, onion, chile, and cilantro into a bowl. Stir everything together until evenly combined.

steps.headline: Mix together the orange juice, lime juice, and salt.
steps.description: Pour the orange juice and lime juice into a separate cup. Add the start, then stir together.

steps.headline: Pour the mixed juices over the salsa.
steps.description: Gently stir the salsa again once more to combine everything.

steps.headline: Chill the salsa before serving it.
steps.description: Cover the salsa with plastic wrap, then chill it in the fridge for 15 to 60 minutes. This allows the different flavors to blend together. It will also make it taste more refreshing.

steps.headline: Prepare you ingredients.
steps.description: Peel, pit, and chop the peaches. Dice the onion. Slice open a red bell pepper, remove the seeds, then dice it up. Mince ½ to 1 jalapeño pepper. Lastly, mince the fresh mint leaves. You can use more than 1 tablespoon (15 grams) of mint for a smoother flavor.

steps.headline: Combine all of the fruits, vegetables, and herbs.
steps.description: Place the peaches into a large mixing bowl. Add the red pepper, onion, and jalapeño pepper. Top it off with the minced mint. Gently stir everything together.

steps.headline: Stir in the lime juice and salt.
steps.description: Squeeze the lime juice over the salsa, then add some salt. Stir everything together once more and give it a taste. If it is not salty enough, add a little bit more salt.

steps.headline: Chill the salsa for 1 hour before serving.
steps.description: Cover the bowl with a sheet of plastic wrap, then place it in the fridge. Leave it there for 1 hour. This allows all of the flavors to blend together. It will also taste more refreshing this way.

steps.headline: Preheat you oven to 350°F (177°C).
steps.description: Cinnamon chips are not mandatory, but they make a great accompaniment to fruit salsa.

steps.headline: Prepare the cinnamon-sugar.
steps.description: Pour the sugar into a bowl. Add the cinnamon, then stir until everything is evenly combined.

steps.headline: Brush some tortillas with melted butter.
steps.description: Buy a pack of 8-inch (20.32-centimeter) flour tortillas. Brush the melted butter onto each tortilla. Make sure that you cover the tortillas evenly, or the cinnamon-sugar won't stick. Melt the butter ahead of time in a small saucepan over the stove. You can also melt it in a microwave-safe dish in the microwave.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the tortillas with the cinnamon sugar.
steps.description: Try to sprinkle the tortillas as evenly as you can. The cinnamon-sugar will stick to the butte, and give the tortillas a sweeter taste.

steps.headline: Cut the tortillas into eighths.
steps.description: You can do this with a sharp knife or with a pizza cutter. You can also cut the tortillas smaller, if you'd prefer.

steps.headline: Transfer the tortillas to an un-greased baking sheet in a single layer.
steps.description: Set the remaining chips aside for a later batch. You won't be able to fit everything on one baking sheet, so plan on baking the chips in batches.

steps.headline: Bake the tortillas for 5 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: The chips are ready when they turn crispy. Once the chips are baked, slide them off onto a cooling rack, and bake the rest in another batch (or two).

steps.headline: Serve the chips with the salsa.
steps.description: Place the chips into a bowl, then set them down on the table alongside the fruit salsa.

text: Making Basic Fruit Salsa Prep your fruits. Peel the kiwis and apples, then core the apples and strawberries. Dice the kiwis, apples, and strawberries. Leave the raspberries whole. For best flavor, use Golden Delicious apples. Combine the ingredients. Toss the diced kiwis into a large bowl. Add the apples, strawberries, and raspberries. Gently stir everything together to combine. Add the sugar and fruit preserves. You can use any flavor of fruit preserves, but strawberry would taste the best. You can also use more or less sugar, depending on your personal tastes. Give your salsa a gentle toss after adding in the sugar and preserves. Chill the salsa for 15 minutes before serving it. Cover the bowl with a sheet of plastic wrap. Place it in the fridge, and leave it there for 15 minutes. This will allow the flavors to blend. It will also make the salsa more refreshing. Making Spicy Tropical Salsa Prepare your ingredients. Peel the papaya and the mango, then slice them in half and remove the seeds/pit. Dice them finely. Peel off the outer layer of the onion. Chop it into fine pieces. Mince the fresh jalapeño chile. You will need the seeds as well. Lastly, chop up the cilantro. Stir the fruits and vegetables together in a bowl. Toss the papaya, mango, onion, chile, and cilantro into a bowl. Stir everything together until evenly combined. Mix together the orange juice, lime juice, and salt. Pour the orange juice and lime juice into a separate cup. Add the start, then stir together. Pour the mixed juices over the salsa. Gently stir the salsa again once more to combine everything. Chill the salsa before serving it. Cover the salsa with plastic wrap, then chill it in the fridge for 15 to 60 minutes. This allows the different flavors to blend together. It will also make it taste more refreshing. Making Spicy Summer Salsa Prepare you ingredients. Peel, pit, and chop the peaches. Dice the onion. Slice open a red bell pepper, remove the seeds, then dice it up. Mince ½ to 1 jalapeño pepper. Lastly, mince the fresh mint leaves. You can use more than 1 tablespoon (15 grams) of mint for a smoother flavor. Combine all of the fruits, vegetables, and herbs. Place the peaches into a large mixing bowl. Add the red pepper, onion, and jalapeño pepper. Top it off with the minced mint. Gently stir everything together. Stir in the lime juice and salt. Squeeze the lime juice over the salsa, then add some salt. Stir everything together once more and give it a taste. If it is not salty enough, add a little bit more salt. Chill the salsa for 1 hour before serving. Cover the bowl with a sheet of plastic wrap, then place it in the fridge. Leave it there for 1 hour. This allows all of the flavors to blend together. It will also taste more refreshing this way. Making Cinnamon Chips (Optional) Preheat you oven to 350°F (177°C). Cinnamon chips are not mandatory, but they make a great accompaniment to fruit salsa. Prepare the cinnamon-sugar. Pour the sugar into a bowl. Add the cinnamon, then stir until everything is evenly combined. Brush some tortillas with melted butter. Buy a pack of 8-inch (20.32-centimeter) flour tortillas. Brush the melted butter onto each tortilla. Make sure that you cover the tortillas evenly, or the cinnamon-sugar won't stick. Melt the butter ahead of time in a small saucepan over the stove. You can also melt it in a microwave-safe dish in the microwave. Sprinkle the tortillas with the cinnamon sugar. Try to sprinkle the tortillas as evenly as you can. The cinnamon-sugar will stick to the butte, and give the tortillas a sweeter taste. Cut the tortillas into eighths. You can do this with a sharp knife or with a pizza cutter. You can also cut the tortillas smaller, if you'd prefer. Transfer the tortillas to an un-greased baking sheet in a single layer. Set the remaining chips aside for a later batch. You won't be able to fit everything on one baking sheet, so plan on baking the chips in batches. Bake the tortillas for 5 to 10 minutes. The chips are ready when they turn crispy. Once the chips are baked, slide them off onto a cooling rack, and bake the rest in another batch (or two). Serve the chips with the salsa. Place the chips into a bowl, then set them down on the table alongside the fruit salsa.
